close_symbols: readers of OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState (all functions that access/inspect GlobalState)
explanation:
For determining whether any operation in OS_ApplicationShutdown is dead code (i.e. its removal would not affect program behaviour) the analyzer needs the following symbols and why:

- OS_SharedGlobalVars
  - To see the definition and lifetime of the global state object being written. Knowing the variable scope and linkage is required to determine visibility and side-effects of the assignment.

- OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState (field)
  - To determine where and how that field is read elsewhere. If GlobalState is never read after this assignment, the assignment is dead code; if it is read (e.g. checked by other tasks), it is live.

- OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER
  - To know the exact value being stored (and whether it matters semantically). The value sometimes encodes a detectable condition; its meaning may affect whether the store influences behavior.

- OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl
  - The call at the end may have side-effects (wake tasks, perform I/O, change other globals). If the call has observable effects, removing it would change behaviour; if it is a no-op, it may be dead. The implementation must be inspected.

- OS_API_Teardown
  - It is the caller of OS_ApplicationShutdown (per the call graph). To decide whether OS_ApplicationShutdown itself is unnecessary, the surrounding teardown sequence must be inspected to see whether OS_ApplicationShutdown's actions are relied upon by the rest of the system.

- OS_IdleLoop
  - The comment indicates the impl should wake the main task that sits in OS_IdleLoop(). Understanding whether OS_IdleLoop reads GlobalState or otherwise reacts to the shutdown call is necessary to judge effect of the assignment and the impl call.

- readers of OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState (all functions that access/inspect GlobalState)
  - A complete list of functions that read or base behavior on GlobalState is required to establish whether writing GlobalState here influences program behaviour elsewhere. If no readers exist (or the readers never run after this write), the assignment is dead.

- true (macro / boolean definition)
  - To confirm the semantics of the comparison (flag == true). If true is non-standard or flag type mismatches, the condition may never or always be true; this affects whether the assignment executes and thus whether it is dead.

- uint8 (typedef)
  - To confirm the width and signedness of flag and whether comparisons with true are meaningful; type promotion/implicit conversion can change runtime behaviour of the if-test.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler and UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData
  - The static call graph shows unit-test wrapper/stub machinery associated with this function. Unit-test hooks can inject extra behavior (handlers, assertions, or alternative flows). To determine real-world (production) vs test-only behavior and whether a call or assignment is effectively executed or has side-effects, the stub/wrapper implementations must be inspected.

Rationale summary: to prove an operation is dead you must show that (a) it executes (or not) in actual runs, and (b) no subsequent code (in any thread/caller/task) depends on its effects. That requires the global written object and all its readers, the called implementation, the calling context, and the relevant type/constant definitions (true/uint8/constant) to be available for analysis.
